Expectation1: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation1: The customer asks about the delivery status
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story:
I was rushing through my delivery route, my phone buzzing with updates and customers tracking their packages in real time. Just as I pulled up to the next stop, my phone rang—another customer, anxious about their order, wanting a precise update. I took a deep breath, remembering the company’s training: always be polite, always be professional, no matter how stressed or behind schedule I felt. I answered, trying to keep my tone calm and helpful, even as my mind raced ahead to the next delivery.

But today was also Election Day, and I had squeezed in a quick stop at the polling station between deliveries. As I handed over my ballot, the poll worker frowned and pointed out a smudge on the envelope. “I’m sorry, but you’ll need to re-sign this so your vote counts,” she said, her voice firm. I glanced at the clock, feeling the pressure of my delivery schedule and the customer still waiting for an answer. I knew I was expected to follow every instruction at the polls, but my job demanded I keep moving and respond quickly. My heart pounded as I stood there, torn between the expectations of my two worlds, unsure which to prioritize.
